pull.title: test: don't throw from the destructor of DebugLogHelper
pull.body:
Throwing an exception from the destructor of a class is a bad practice because the destructor will be called when an object of that type is alive on the stack and another exception is thrown, which will result in "exception during the exception". This would terminate the program without any messages.

Instead print the message to the standard error output and call `std::abort()`.

---

This change is part of https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26812. It is an improvement on its own, so creating a separate PR for it following the discussion at https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32604#discussion_r2345091587. Getting it in will reduce the size of #26812.

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.
<!--5faf32d7da4f0f540f40219e4f7537a3-->

ACK 7f87cddd36f0456be52d795a53887d53294f824e

I've reviewed, I've executed the unit tests.
The change is Test only.
The relevant change is in `DebugLogHelper` destructor, exception throwing is replaced by print and `abort()`.
Other changes improve documentation, parameters of the class.
Changes are not in separate commits, but changes are small and test-only.

> Throwing an exception from the destructor of a class is a bad practice because the destructor will be called when an object of that type is alive on the stack and another exception is thrown, which will result in "exception during the exception". This would terminate the program without any messages.

This is not precisely what happens. If an exception is emitted from a function marked `noexcept(false)`, the current terminate handler will be invoked. It does not matter whether the destructor is called due to another exception or not.
The default terminate handler would print the exception and then call abort.

The proposed implementation prints the error and then calls abort.

So basically, the change is that the class is no longer sensitive to a custom terminate handler. Is that really desired?

Cap'n Proto has a policy of declaring destructors `noexcept(false)` and using `std::uncaught_exception()` to prevent throwing more than once under the assumption that "ff another exception is already active, the new exception is assumed to be a side-effect of the main exception, and is either silently swallowed or reported on a side channel." It seems like that could be a reasonable approach here. The DebugLogHelper destructor could continue to throw normally, but just log instead in the case where another exception was active. And if caller cared to prevent this, it could call the `check_found` method explicitly outside of the destructor.

More information about cap'n proto's policy:

- https://github.com/capnproto/capnproto/blob/master/style-guide.md#exceptions-can-happen-anywhere-including-destructors
- https://github.com/capnproto/capnproto/blob/master/style-guide.md#exceptions-usage
- https://github.com/capnproto/capnproto/blob/master/doc/cxx.md#c-feature-usage--c11-exceptions

Not endorsing it generally but it might be a good fit here.

> using std::uncaught_exception() to prevent throwing

https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/error/uncaught_exception.html indicates `std::uncaught_exception()` is deprecated in C++17 and removed in C++20 - but we could use `std::uncaught_exceptions()`.

Added a few comments, thanks for tackling this.
As `DebugLogHelper` is only used within the unit test framework; could use `BOOST_REQUIRE` with a message within the destructor too.

events.body: `7f87cddd36...ba6689aa9e`: drop some unrelated changes and pick some suggestions

verification.payload:
tree 8af44bf2c6e375a88138f9ab3f18f30ee84e1727
parent ba6689aa9e3230a15ef9080a34a1c49c01f229b0
author Daniel Pfeifer <daniel@pfeifer-mail.de> 1758205979 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1758205979 +0200

test: forbid copying of DebugLogHelper

events.body:
> If an exception is emitted from a function marked `noexcept(false)`, the current terminate handler will be invoked.

My bad. That is the behavior for `noexcept(true)`, of course. I agree that marking a destructor with `noexcept(false)` is bad.

re: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/33388#issuecomment-3307790546

> The swallowing of the 2nd and subsequent exceptions seems to assume that one has control and has implemented the same policy in all destructors in the program.

That's not true, and wanted to be clear I wasn't advocating the policy generally. I was just pointing out that letting this particular destructor throw as it was designed to do, instead of aborting, is easy to support in practice with the noexcept(false) std::uncaught_exceptions technique. And it seems like a nice and safe way to provide error feedback. But if you think it's better to abort, that also seems fine.

Core review ACK 2dcf0c69b8659886ecfc85b174e59cd7f210f5c0

I would also prefer adding quotes around the message but it's not a blocker.

comments.body: Please add `#include <cstdlib>` for [std::abort()](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/program/abort)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -8,10 +8,10 @@
 #include <noui.h>
 #include <tinyformat.h>
 
-#include <stdexcept>
+#include <iostream>
 
-DebugLogHelper::DebugLogHelper(std::string message, MatchFn match)
-    : m_message{std::move(message)}, m_match(std::move(match))
+DebugLogHelper::DebugLogHelper(const std::string& message, MatchFn match)
comments.body:
This parameter change is a separate concern. Please split it into its own commit to keep the risky behavior change easy to review.
Though personally, I'd pass both by value and move into the members to handle rvalues efficiently.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -11,29 +11,46 @@
 #include <list>
 #include <string>
 
+/**
+ * A helper class that ensures a given message is logged within the scope of an instance of the class.
+ */
 class DebugLogHelper
 {
+public:
+    using MatchFn = std::function<bool(const std::string* line)>;
+
+    /**
+     * Construct an instance, providing the message and possibly a custom
+     * matching function.
+     * @param[in] message This message must be logged after this instance
+     * is created and before it is destroyed.
+     * @param[in] match Custom match checking function. Invoked:
+     * - when a new message is logged which contains `message`
+     *   - if it returns `true`, then a match is considered to have been found, thus:
+     *     - further checking of log messages is not done
+     *     - this function will not be called for the rest of the logged messages
+     *     - the destructor `~DebugLogHelper()` will not do any checks
+     *   - if it returns `false`, then the current message logged is not considered a match, thus:
+     *     - subsequent log messages will be checked for `message`
+     *     - this function will be called if any is found
+     *     - eventually, if the destructor `~DebugLogHelper()` is called and this function
+     *       never returned `true`, then it will call it once more for a last time with a
+     *       `nullptr` argument.
+     * - if the destructor is called without a successful match, then this function will be
+     *   called with a `nullptr` argument to decide what the final action should be:
+     *   - if it returns `true`, then a fatal error will be produced
+     *   - if it returns `false`, then the no-match will be ignored and operation will
+     *     continue normally
+     */
comments.body:
I'm very much against these long and scary comments - seems like a strong code smell. The comment will quickly reflect an old version of the code since it's not high-level enough and we simply won't update it when the code changes. And honestly reading the whole thing didn't help me with understanding the gist of it.

If we feel the code isn't self-explanatory we should adjust the code instead of writing long documentation for it. If you still feel docs are needed, let's do it more high-level without all the details that the code can already tell us, maybe something like:

```suggestion
    /**
     * RAII test helper that asserts a log line containing `message` is emitted during its lifetime.
     * The optional `match` predicate is called for each such line, and once at destruction with `nullptr`, if none.
     * If that final call returns true, an error is printed and the process aborts (default).
     */
```
`LogError` would flush after this line, so we could safely abort after (since `abort` doesn't call any destructors). Can you confirm that `cerr` will also flush safely?
I admit that I don't understand this well enough, why reconnect before deleting the callback? Shouldn't we delete the callback first, then call `noui_reconnect()`?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -11,29 +11,46 @@
 #include <list>
 #include <string>
 
+/**
+ * A helper class that ensures a given message is logged within the scope of an instance of the class.
+ */
 class DebugLogHelper
 {
+public:
+    using MatchFn = std::function<bool(const std::string* line)>;
+
+    /**
+     * Construct an instance, providing the message and possibly a custom
+     * matching function.
+     * @param[in] message This message must be logged after this instance
+     * is created and before it is destroyed.
+     * @param[in] match Custom match checking function. Invoked:
+     * - when a new message is logged which contains `message`
+     *   - if it returns `true`, then a match is considered to have been found, thus:
+     *     - further checking of log messages is not done
+     *     - this function will not be called for the rest of the logged messages
+     *     - the destructor `~DebugLogHelper()` will not do any checks
+     *   - if it returns `false`, then the current message logged is not considered a match, thus:
+     *     - subsequent log messages will be checked for `message`
+     *     - this function will be called if any is found
+     *     - eventually, if the destructor `~DebugLogHelper()` is called and this function
+     *       never returned `true`, then it will call it once more for a last time with a
+     *       `nullptr` argument.
+     * - if the destructor is called without a successful match, then this function will be
+     *   called with a `nullptr` argument to decide what the final action should be:
+     *   - if it returns `true`, then a fatal error will be produced
+     *   - if it returns `false`, then the no-match will be ignored and operation will
+     *     continue normally
+     */
+    explicit DebugLogHelper(const std::string& message, MatchFn match = [](const std::string*){ return true; });
comments.body:
nit: we can simplify it a bit (+ pass by value mentioned earlier):
```suggestion
    explicit DebugLogHelper(std::string message, MatchFn match = [](auto){ return true; });
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -8,10 +8,10 @@
 #include <noui.h>
 #include <tinyformat.h>
 
-#include <stdexcept>
+#include <iostream>
 
-DebugLogHelper::DebugLogHelper(std::string message, MatchFn match)
-    : m_message{std::move(message)}, m_match(std::move(match))
+DebugLogHelper::DebugLogHelper(const std::string& message, MatchFn match)
+    : m_message{message}, m_match(std::move(match))
comments.body: The `message` parameter was optimized to `const std::string&`, but `match` still uses pass-by-value. For consistency, shouldn't `match` also be `const MatchFn&`?

 #include <tinyformat.h>
 
-#include <stdexcept>
+#include <iostream>

-    : m_message{std::move(message)}, m_match(std::move(match))

comments.body: This commit mixes exception safety fixes with parameter optimization. Like @l0rinc mention perhaps consider splitting the parameter changes into a separate commit for cleaner git history and easier debugging.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -8,10 +8,10 @@
 #include <noui.h>
 #include <tinyformat.h>
 
-#include <stdexcept>
+#include <iostream>
 
-DebugLogHelper::DebugLogHelper(std::string message, MatchFn match)
-    : m_message{std::move(message)}, m_match(std::move(match))
+DebugLogHelper::DebugLogHelper(const std::string& message, MatchFn match)
+    : m_message{message}, m_match(std::move(match))
comments.body: I prefer passing both by value and moving into the members, since most call sites pass temporaries from string literals for the message.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -8,10 +8,10 @@
 #include <noui.h>
 #include <tinyformat.h>
 
-#include <stdexcept>
+#include <iostream>
 
-DebugLogHelper::DebugLogHelper(std::string message, MatchFn match)
-    : m_message{std::move(message)}, m_match(std::move(match))
+DebugLogHelper::DebugLogHelper(const std::string& message, MatchFn match)
+    : m_message{message}, m_match(std::move(match))
comments.body: Good point. Using pass-by-value + move for both parameters would indeed solve the consistency issue while being optimal for the common case of string literals. That approach makes both parameters follow the same pattern.
Done.

comments.body: Reverted to the original comment and its location.
Could add `std::cerr.flush()`, but I think it is not necessary because [cerr is unbuffered](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/cpp/difference-between-cerr-and-clog/).
Hmm, I am not sure either. Maybe it should be done like you say. Unrelated to this PR.

@@ -8,10 +8,10 @@

comments.body: Dropped altogether.
The original error had the message string in quotes. I think this should be preserved because it is easier to debug when the string contains whitespace at the end.
That is my understanding as well, thanks
nit/unrelated: I'm surprised to see an `std::list` here, `std::vector` is likely faster even for random erases
